required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Comparative Effectiveness Between Microprocessor Knees and Non-Microprocessor Knees
clinical_study.official_title: Comparative Effectiveness Between Microprocessor Knees and Non-Microprocessor Knees

brief_summary.textblock: This study will assess if the functional performance and musculoskeletal outcome of transfemoral amputees are improved after receiving a Microprocessor Knee (MPK) compared to a Non-Microprocessor Knees (NMPK).

detailed_description.textblock: The study design is a reversal design whereby only the prosthetic knee joint will be changed. Each subject will be tested using their current NMPK, fit and tested with a MPK, and then tested again with their NMPK. MPK prostheses from all manufacturers will be considered appropriate for testing. Each MPK to be used in this study is FDA approved. The foot will be in the L5981 class, e.g. flex foot or equivalent. The same socket, suspension, and foot will be used throughout the study in order to eliminate these confounding variables. All prosthesis fittings will be performed by the subject's own certified prosthetist according to manufacturers' fitting guidelines.

primary_outcome.measure: Daily Activity Measured With Triaxial Accelerometers
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (tested on subjects' current NMPK), 10 weeks (after 10 weeks acclimation time to the study MPK) , 4 weeks (subjects placed back on NMPK and tested after 4 weeks re-acclimation time)
primary_outcome.description: Measurements will be obtained three times using activity monitors attached to waist, and bilaterally to the ankle and thigh for a period of 4 consecutive days, including 2 weekdays and 2 weekend days. Primary outcome will be the difference in activity level between the NMPK and MPK measurements.

primary_outcome.measure: Falls as Assessed by the Prosthesis Evaluation Questionnaire Addendum (PEQ-A)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (tested on subjects' current NMPK), 10 weeks (after 10 weeks acclimation time to the study MPK) , 4 weeks (subjects placed back on NMPK and tested after 4 weeks re-acclimation time)
primary_outcome.description: The Prosthesis Evaluation Questionnaire (PEQ) addendum (PEQ-A) is a self-administered questionnaire to quantify balance confidence, concentration, stumbles, and falls. The outcome will be difference in falls per month between the Non-Microprocessor Knee (NPMK) and MPK measurements. The number of falls was recorded as the sum of items #5 and #7 in the PEQ-A.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient Satisfaction as Assessed by the Prosthesis Evaluation Questionnaire (PEQ)
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (tested on subjects' current NMPK), 10 weeks (after 10 weeks acclimation time to the study MPK) , 4 weeks (subjects placed back on NMPK and tested after 4 weeks re-acclimation time)
secondary_outcome.description: The condition-specific Prosthesis Evaluation Questionnaire (PEQ) was used to quantify patient satisfaction with each prosthesis. The outcome was a difference in PEQ scores between the NPMK and MPK measurements. The PEQ is a self-administered questionnaire composed of nine validated scales (ambulation, appearance, frustration, perceived response, residual limb health, social burden, sounds, utility, well being). Scores range from 0 to 100 for each sub-scale. Higher scores indicated a higher functioning prosthesis/quality of life.

arm_group.description: Each subject will be tested using their current Non-Microprocessor Knee (NMPK) , fit and tested with a Microprocessor Knee (MPK), and then tested again with their NMPK, e.g. A-B-A design.

intervention.description: MPKs are prosthetic knees that use a microprocessor to control the prosthetic knee mechanism and adjust knee stiffness.
A NMPK is a mechanical knee with either hydraulic or pneumatic controls.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Unilateral transfemoral amputee
- Medicare Functional Classification Level K2 or K3
- Currently using NMPK prosthesis
- No current residual limb problems, such as skin breakdown
- Able to ambulate without a gait aid
Exclusion Criteria:
- Previous stroke or other neuromuscular complications currently affecting gait
- Currently undergoing dialysis treatments
- Amputation of the contralateral limb
- Poor fit of current NMPK prosthesis

results_reference.citation: Kaufman KR, Bernhardt KA, Symms K. Functional assessment and satisfaction of transfemoral amputees with low mobility (FASTK2): A clinical trial of microprocessor-controlled vs. non-microprocessor-controlled knees. Clin Biomech (Bristol, Avon). 2018 Oct;58:116-122. doi: 10.1016/j.clinbiomech.2018.07.012. Epub 2018 Jul 19.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Professor of Biomedical Engineering, College of Medicine

provided_document.document_type: Study Protocol and Statistical Analysis Plan

group.title: Prosthetic Knee Joints
group.description: Each subject will be tested using their current Non-Microprocessor Knee (NMPK) , fit and tested with a Microprocessor Knee (MPK), and then tested again with their NMPK, e.g. A-B-A design. Microprocessor Knee (MPK): MPKs are prosthetic knees that use a microprocessor to control the prosthetic knee mechanism and adjust knee stiffness. Non-Microprocessor Knee (NMPK): A NMPK is a mechanical knee with either hydraulic or pneumatic controls.

group.title: Prosthetic Knee Joints
group.description: Each subject will be tested using their current Non-Microprocessor Knee (NMPK) , fit and tested with a Microprocessor Knee (MPK), and then tested again with their NMPK, e.g. A-B-A design. Microprocessor Knee (MPK): MPKs are prosthetic knees that use a microprocessor to control the prosthetic knee mechanism and adjust knee stiffness. Non-Microprocessor Knee (NMPK): A NMPK is a mechanical knee with either hydraulic or pneumatic controls.

measure.title: Race and Ethnicity Not Collected
measure.population: Race and Ethnicity were not collected from any participant.

outcome.title: Daily Activity Measured With Triaxial Accelerometers
outcome.description: Measurements will be obtained three times using activity monitors attached to waist, and bilaterally to the ankle and thigh for a period of 4 consecutive days, including 2 weekdays and 2 weekend days. Primary outcome will be the difference in activity level between the NMPK and MPK measurements.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline (tested on subjects' current NMPK), 10 weeks (after 10 weeks acclimation time to the study MPK) , 4 weeks (subjects placed back on NMPK and tested after 4 weeks re-acclimation time)
outcome.population: Activity measurement data were available for analysis on 46 baseline participants, 31 MPK participants, and 18 NMPK participants.

group.title: Prosthetic Knee Joints
group.description: Each subject will be tested using their current Non-Microprocessor Knee (NMPK) , fit and tested with a Microprocessor Knee (MPK), and then tested again with their NMPK, e.g. A-B-A design. Microprocessor Knee (MPK): MPKs are prosthetic knees that use a microprocessor to control the prosthetic knee mechanism and adjust knee stiffness. Non-Microprocessor Knee (NMPK): A NMPK is a mechanical knee with either hydraulic or pneumatic controls.

measure.title: Daily Activity Measured With Triaxial Accelerometers
measure.description: Measurements will be obtained three times using activity monitors attached to waist, and bilaterally to the ankle and thigh for a period of 4 consecutive days, including 2 weekdays and 2 weekend days. Primary outcome will be the difference in activity level between the NMPK and MPK measurements.
measure.population: Activity measurement data were available for analysis on 46 baseline participants, 31 MPK participants, and 18 NMPK participants.

outcome.title: Falls as Assessed by the Prosthesis Evaluation Questionnaire Addendum (PEQ-A)
outcome.description: The Prosthesis Evaluation Questionnaire (PEQ) addendum (PEQ-A) is a self-administered questionnaire to quantify balance confidence, concentration, stumbles, and falls. The outcome will be difference in falls per month between the Non-Microprocessor Knee (NPMK) and MPK measurements. The number of falls was recorded as the sum of items #5 and #7 in the PEQ-A.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline (tested on subjects' current NMPK), 10 weeks (after 10 weeks acclimation time to the study MPK) , 4 weeks (subjects placed back on NMPK and tested after 4 weeks re-acclimation time)
outcome.population: Data for falls were available for analysis on 46 baseline participants, 30 MPK participants, and 17 NMPK participants.

group.title: Prosthetic Knee Joints
group.description: Each subject will be tested using their current Non-Microprocessor Knee (NMPK) , fit and tested with a Microprocessor Knee (MPK), and then tested again with their NMPK, e.g. A-B-A design. Microprocessor Knee (MPK): MPKs are prosthetic knees that use a microprocessor to control the prosthetic knee mechanism and adjust knee stiffness. Non-Microprocessor Knee (NMPK): A NMPK is a mechanical knee with either hydraulic or pneumatic controls.

measure.title: Falls as Assessed by the Prosthesis Evaluation Questionnaire Addendum (PEQ-A)
measure.description: The Prosthesis Evaluation Questionnaire (PEQ) addendum (PEQ-A) is a self-administered questionnaire to quantify balance confidence, concentration, stumbles, and falls. The outcome will be difference in falls per month between the Non-Microprocessor Knee (NPMK) and MPK measurements. The number of falls was recorded as the sum of items #5 and #7 in the PEQ-A.
measure.population: Data for falls were available for analysis on 46 baseline participants, 30 MPK participants, and 17 NMPK participants.

outcome.title: Patient Satisfaction as Assessed by the Prosthesis Evaluation Questionnaire (PEQ)
outcome.description: The condition-specific Prosthesis Evaluation Questionnaire (PEQ) was used to quantify patient satisfaction with each prosthesis. The outcome was a difference in PEQ scores between the NPMK and MPK measurements. The PEQ is a self-administered questionnaire composed of nine validated scales (ambulation, appearance, frustration, perceived response, residual limb health, social burden, sounds, utility, well being). Scores range from 0 to 100 for each sub-scale. Higher scores indicated a higher functioning prosthesis/quality of life.
outcome.time_frame: Baseline (tested on subjects' current NMPK), 10 weeks (after 10 weeks acclimation time to the study MPK) , 4 weeks (subjects placed back on NMPK and tested after 4 weeks re-acclimation time)
outcome.population: Not all participants completed all the scales in the questionnaire.

group.title: Prosthetic Knee Joints - NMPK Baseline
group.description: Each subject will be tested using their current Non-Microprocessor Knee (NMPK) , fit and tested with a Microprocessor Knee (MPK), and then tested again with their NMPK, e.g. A-B-A design. Microprocessor Knee (MPK): MPKs are prosthetic knees that use a microprocessor to control the prosthetic knee mechanism and adjust knee stiffness. Non-Microprocessor Knee (NMPK): A NMPK is a mechanical knee with either hydraulic or pneumatic controls.

measure.title: Patient Satisfaction as Assessed by the Prosthesis Evaluation Questionnaire (PEQ)
measure.description: The condition-specific Prosthesis Evaluation Questionnaire (PEQ) was used to quantify patient satisfaction with each prosthesis. The outcome was a difference in PEQ scores between the NPMK and MPK measurements. The PEQ is a self-administered questionnaire composed of nine validated scales (ambulation, appearance, frustration, perceived response, residual limb health, social burden, sounds, utility, well being). Scores range from 0 to 100 for each sub-scale. Higher scores indicated a higher functioning prosthesis/quality of life.
measure.population: Not all participants completed all the scales in the questionnaire.

reported_events.time_frame: Acclimation period through assessment after reversion to the NMPK, up 6 months.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: All Principal Investigators ARE employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.
